title: Conceptualization of Human Soccer Concepts to Robotic Soccer Architecture
technology: Simulation, RoboCup, computer vision, AI systems, software frameworks
p: ** Human soccer coaches, players, teams, and match dynamics.
i: ** Proposed definitions of concepts like coach, player, role, play/move, formation, tactic, and strategy.
c: **  - The abstract doesn’t explicitly compare different approaches or treatments.
o: **  The ability to describe teams, strategies, and match dynamics effectively to inform the design of a robotic soccer architecture. Specifically, facilitating the implementation and testing within the RoboCup simulation category.

title: Performing more than 20 purposeful gameplay headers in a soccer season may alter autonomic function in female youth soccer players
p: ** Female youth soccer players (specifically, those categorized as having <20 headers per season vs. >20 headers per season).
i: ** Performing more than 20 purposeful soccer headers during a soccer season.
c: **  - The study did not include a control group.
o: ** Measures of heart rate variability (HRV), including standard deviation of the normal-normal intervals, total power, high frequency (HF), low frequency (LF), LF:HF, normalized HF and normalized LF.

title: Perceived Soccer Literacy: A Construct Linking Soccer Video Games Play to Soccer Engagement
technology: Video analysis, structural equation modeling, latent variable path analysis
p: ** US and Canadian adults who do not physically play soccer regularly.
i: ** Use of soccer video games.
c: **  (There isn't a defined comparison group in the abstract).
o: ** Perceived soccer literacy (measured by affective attitude, perceived functional knowledge, perceived critical knowledge, and perceived competence), soccer involvement, and behavioral intentions.

title: Direct player observation is needed to accurately quantify heading frequency in youth soccer
p: ** 12 female youth soccer players
i: ** Self-reported average number of headers per game
c: ** Actual number of headers extracted from game video
o: **  Self-reported headers overestimated the number of headers by 51% (compared to actual headers).

title: Soccer-Specific Endurance and Running Economy in Soccer Players With Cerebral Palsy
technology: wearables, Yo-Yo intermittent recovery run, treadmill, biomechanics, force plates, motion capture, computer vision
p: ** Soccer players with Cerebral Palsy (SPCP) – specifically, fourteen international male soccer players with cerebral palsy from the Irish CP team.
i: ** “Yo-Yo” intermittent recovery run level 1 (IRL-1) test (to assess soccer-specific endurance) and a submaximal running test on a treadmill (to determine running economy).
c: ** Position-matched soccer players without disability.
o: ** Soccer-specific endurance (distance covered on IRL-1 test), running economy, and selected kinematic running criteria.

title: Soccer, images and professionalization: soccer plays with every teenage dream
p: ** Adolescents aged 13 to 16 years old who practice soccer (nine adolescents)
i: ** Open interviews, analysis of discourses (Maingueneau, 1998) and examination of the categories “dream” and “images” (Auge, 1994)
c: **  - The study doesn't explicitly compare different groups. It focuses on understanding motivations within the participants.
o: ** Motivators for continuing the dream of teenagers to become professional soccer players (family, television media, and the soccer anonymous).

title: Leadership Power Perceptions of Soccer Coaches and Soccer Players According to Their Education
technology: Kruskal-Wallis Test, Mann-Whitney Test, Power in Soccer Questionnaire-Other, Power in Soccer Questionnaire-Self, information form
p: ** Male soccer coaches (165) and male soccer players (870)
i: **  Use of the “Power in Soccer Questionnaire-Other”, “Power in Soccer Questionnaire-Self” and an “information form” to assess leadership power perceptions.
c: **  (The study doesn’t explicitly compare groups to a control.  The analysis focuses on differences within the two groups.)
o: ** Perception of Coercive Power (players vs. education level), Referent Power (players vs. education level), Legitimate Power (coaches vs. education level), and Expert Power (players vs. education level).

title: The biomechanics of soccer: A review
technology: force plates, motion capture, biomechanical modelling, computer vision, simulation studies
p: ** Soccer players (specifically those involved in kicking and related skills)
i: ** Kicking technique (specifically the maximum velocity instep kick), equipment (boots, ball, turf surfaces), instruction and skill development.
c: **  - The article primarily focuses on describing and understanding the biomechanical factors rather than comparing interventions.
o: ** Performance (kicking velocity, technical skill), injury incidence and severity (ankle inversion, surface-related injuries, potentially long-term brain damage from heading), player-equipment interaction.

title: Evidence on soccer-specific stadiums and attendance: The Major League Soccer case
technology: Regression model, AI (modeling), sensors (weather conditions), data collection (game observations)
p: ** Major League Soccer (MLS) teams (represented by the 2538 observations of regular season games)
i: ** Soccer-specific stadiums, uncertainty of outcome, performance of teams, weather conditions, year, month, and game day.
c: **  - There isn’t a direct comparison group explicitly stated in the abstract.
o: ** Logarithm of attendance.

title: Assessing visual attention using soccer game videos in elite female soccer player
technology: video analysis, computer vision, motion capture, tracking accuracy,
p: ** Female soccer players (14 Chinese female soccer players) and Non-soccer players (20 Chinese female non-soccer players)
i: ** Video-based Multiple Object Tracking (MOT) task with varying numbers of targets (4, 6, or 8 targets)
c: **  - While the study compares soccer players to non-soccer players, there isn’t a specific control condition like a placebo intervention.
o: ** Tracking accuracy (specifically, dynamic visual attention features) - measured across various target quantities.

title: Brief Analysis of the Influence NBA Basketball Culture on Chinese Basketball Culture
p: ** Chinese basketball culture (as the subject of analysis)
i: ** Influence of American NBA basketball culture
c: **  (The abstract doesn’t explicitly state a comparison group)

title: The Application of Basketball Game in College Basketball Teaching
p: ** College students (specifically, graduate students participating in physical education)
i: ** Use of basketball games in college basketball teaching (implementation of game-based teaching methods)
c: **  – The abstract doesn’t explicitly detail a comparison group. It implicitly compares game-based teaching to traditional methods, but doesn’t state it.
o: ** Improvement of physical quality, enhancement of physical and mental health, optimization of the teaching process, improvement of teaching effectiveness, promotion of student interest in learning.

title: Investigation of Chinese Basketball Coaches in Basketball-Based High School
p: ** Chinese Basketball Coaches in Chinese basketball-based high schools
i: ** Training status, professionalism, teaching ability, knowledge level (of the coaches)
o: ** Basic situation (of the coaches), training status, professionalism, teaching ability, knowledge level

title: Physiological Responses and Technical-Tactical Performance of Youth Basketball Players: A Brief Comparison between 3x3 and 5x5 Basketball
technology: video analysis, heart rate, biomechanics, sensors
p: ** Youth male basketball players (16.6 ?? 0.2 years old)
i: ** Playing simulated 3x3 (half-court) and 5x5 (full-court) basketball games.
c: **  - The study doesn't explicitly compare an intervention to a control group; it focuses on observing differences *within* the two game conditions.
o: ** Physiological responses (heart rate, muscle oxygen saturation, total hemoglobin data – specifically, sample entropy of hemoglobin) and technical-tactical performance (measured via video analysis).

title: Basketball Action Data Processing Method Based on Mode Symmetric Algorithm
technology: computer vision, machine learning, video analysis, sensors, motion capture, biomechanics, ESMD, AGM curve
p: ** Athletes / Basketball players / Individuals performing basketball actions

title: From European Basketball Progress to Explore the Development of Chinese Men's Basketball

p: ** Chinese basketball training practitioners / coaches / administrators (implied participants in analyzing the impact)
i: ** Basketball rule changes

o: **  Influence/Effect of basketball rule changes on Chinese basketball training guiding ideology and the “subdue factor.” (Specifically, understanding the variation and direction of the subdue factor).

p: ** Basketball players (specifically, young people concerned about NBA/CBA)

p: ** Students (specifically, students in volleyball skills and tactics teaching)

c: **  – The abstract doesn’t explicitly mention a comparison or control group. It focuses on the strategies themselves.
o: ** Development of students' volleyball consciousness, improvement of students’ level and applicability of skills and tactics, and good coordination between volleyball consciousness and skills/tactics.

title: Thought on the Application of Volleyball Games to Volleyball Teaching
p: ** College volleyball students
i: ** Application of volleyball games to volleyball teaching
c: **  (Traditional teacher demonstration and student compliance)
o: ** Arouse students’ learning interests, improve student engagement with volleyball.

title: Analysis of Effects of Volleyball Competition Regulations Change and Development on Volleyball Sport

i: ** Changes in volleyball competition regulations (specifically, the stages of origin, developing, completed, and professional/semi-professional)
c: **  - The abstract doesn’t explicitly state a comparison group or control. It focuses on the effects of the changes themselves.
o: ** Effects on strategy, sport structure, team, athlete selection, and training methods.

title: Scheduling the Italian National Volleyball Tournament
p: ** Italian Volleyball League (teams participating in the tournament)
i: ** A sports scheduling approach/model using mathematical programming solvers.
c: **  – There isn’t a defined comparison group in this abstract. The model is being tested against previous seasons' tournaments.
o: ** Production of a high-quality schedule that balances matches and ensures adequate media coverage.

title: Injuries in Youth Volleyball Players at a National Championship: Incidence, Risk Factors, and Mechanisms of Injury
technology: motion capture, video analysis, biomechanics, force plates, EMG, AI
p: ** Youth volleyball players (specifically, 776 players – 466 males, 1391 females, with a mean age of 16.2 years)
i: ** Participation in the 2018 Canadian Youth National Volleyball Tournament.  (Essentially, being exposed to the tournament environment)
c: **  - The study didn’t compare an intervention to a control group.
o: ** Injury incidence rates, types of injury (joint sprain, concussion), mechanisms of injury (ball-to-head contact), and potential risk factors (sex, age group, position, underage status).

title: Recovery in volleyball
p: ** Volleyball players (specifically, players participating in competitive matches)
i: ** Recovery strategies (including types of active recovery or passive rest)
c: **  -  There isn’t a direct comparison group described in the abstract. The review focuses on optimizing recovery without a defined alternative.
o: ** Fatigue induced and its underlying mechanisms (related to recovery effectiveness)

title: EFFECTS OF WHOLE BODY VIBRATION ON STRENGTH AND JUMPING PERFORMANCE IN VOLLEYBALL AND BEACH VOLLEYBALL PLAYERS
technology: Ergo Tester, force plates, computer vision, machine learning, sensors, biomechanics, wearable sensors
p: ** Sub-elite male volleyball (VB; n=12) and beach volleyball players (BVB; n=11) aged 21.2 +/- 3.0 years.
i: ** 6-week strength training with whole body vibration (WBV) (30-40 Hz, 1.7-2.5 mm, 3.0-5.7 g) vs. traditional strength training.
c: ** Traditional strength training.
o: ** Leg strength (measured by Squat jump (Si) and countermovement squat jump (CMJ) measurements by the Ergo Tester contact platform and maximum leg press test (1RM)) and jump performance.

title: Landing Techniques in Beach Volleyball
technology: video analysis, motion capture, biomechanics, force plates, chi-squared analysis
p: ** Professional Beach Volleyball players (specifically, men and women)
i: ** Landing techniques (two-footed, left-footed, and right-footed landings) following serve, set, attack, and block actions.
c: ** Landing techniques in indoor volleyball.
o: ** Differences in landing frequency and foot placement between men and women, and between beach volleyball and indoor volleyball players;  reduction in injury rates.

title: Development of Gas-volleyball
p: ** College students, people of different ages needing fitness and entertainment.
i: ** Development of “Gas-volleyball” and “Fitness Volleyball” (a type of recreational volleyball).
c: ** Professional volleyball sports.
o: ** Suitability for different populations, spread, training volleyball successors, fitness and entertainment.

title: Self-reported symptoms and risk factors for digital ischaemia among international world-class beach volleyball players
p: ** World-class beach volleyball players (specifically, those active during the 2013 Grand Slam Beach Volleyball in the Netherlands)
i: ** Self-reported symptoms (specifically, cold or blue or pale digits in the dominant hand during or immediately after practice or competition) and volleyball playing experience (length of career - >14 years).
c: **  – The study doesn’t directly compare the symptoms to a control group.
o: ** Prevalence of ischaemia-related symptoms (cold/blue/pale digits) and risk factors associated with these symptoms (length of playing career > 14 years, and sex). Specifically, the study measures the odds ratio for each risk factor.

title: TENNIS FOR PHYSICAL HEALTH: ACUTE AGE- AND GENDER-BASED PHYSIOLOGICAL RESPONSES TO CARDIO TENNIS
technology: video analysis, motion capture, sensors, pedometer, biomechanics, force plates, HR, computer vision
p: ** Active participants – Specifically, younger and older adult males and females with prior recreational tennis experience (approx. 2 years).
i: ** Cardio tennis – A 50-minute instructor-led conditioning-based tennis program including warm-up movements, drill-based exercises, and competitive play scenarios.
c: **  – There is no specific comparison group mentioned in the abstract.
o: ** Physiological responses including: Heart rate (HR), Blood pressure (BP), Rate pressure product (RPP), Capillary blood lactate and glucose, Step counts, Stroke counts, Ratings of perceived exertion, and perceived challenge.

title: The Hit Turn Tennis Test: An acoustically controlled endurance test for tennis players
technology: ball machine, force plates, sensors, video analysis, computer vision, biomechanics
p: ** Competitive tennis players (53 males, 45 females) of different age groups.
i: ** Hit Turn Tennis Test (acoustically progressive on-court endurance test) – specifically, completion of three tests on clay and carpet surfaces, and a tennis-specific ball machine test.
c: ** Incremental treadmill run; Tennis-specific ball machine test.
o: ** Maximal performance (measured on the Hit Turn test and ball machine test); Maximal oxygen uptake (correlation with Hit Turn test); Correlation between maximal performance and age group (specifically, boys vs. girls).

title: Tennis Patterns Recognition Based on a Novel Tennis Dataset - 3DTennisDS

c: ** THETIS dataset (markerless/marker-based), Tennis-Mocap dataset (marker-based)
o: ** Accuracy of human action recognition, classification of tennis movements, impact of data fuzzification on classification results.

title: Epidemiology of Musculoskeletal Injury in the Paddle-tennis Players in Comparison with Tennis Players
technology: biomechanics, force plates, IPAQ questionnaire, video analysis
